VI-16
Sir: we should be most honoured. But will not such a thing sadly
disturb your table of precedence?
Table of Precedence J Not here, not over here l Plague take such
a thing l The nearest we get to a table of precedence is that
meeting we had last night in your house, Ned.
I agree.
We just sat down with half a dozen of the leading citizens and
thrashed it all out; where the wagons were to go, where the
Fourth of July Orator wss to march (T hope you®re ready for some
long speeches) and that Just about settled it.
How long will y^u be here, Azariah?
Oh, perhaps, half an hour.
I®11 just slip home then and bring back half a dozen or so
pamphlets and leave them about the hotel. This outfit wouldn'J
serve spirits at breakfast If the guests had some of my. pictures
before their eyes. See you later, gentlemen I
Remarkable man, Mr. Delavan. Don’t you think so, sir?
Oh, I agree. Publishes all that at his own expense.
He®s rich. Fortunes, fortunes. The man’s a millionaire. He can
afford it. Kay not look much, but he could buy up any one In
Albany half a dozen times over.
Kay I ask how he acquired his fortune?
What a question ®. (FLAGG AND LIVINGSTONE LAUGII)
Is the question Inappropriate; if so, forgive us...
Not inappropriate, no.,,
But you’ll be surprised at the answer. He made his money in
liquor: wines and spirits. Strong drink. Detnon rum. Booze.
When that man talks about alcohol, he knows what he’s talking
about. He dealt largely in the wine business; and when he saw
